newsitem.title: IRAN: Iranians in Malaysia choose Khatami by landslide.
newsitem.headline: Iranians in Malaysia choose Khatami by landslide.

text.p: If the 206 Iranian expatriates who voted in Malaysia on Friday reflect the mood of Iran's 33 million-strong electorate, moderate Mohammad Khatami will win the Islamic republic's presidency with a landslide.
As voting continued in Iran, the Iranian news agency IRNA said out of 206 votes cast by Iranians living in Malyasia Khatami led the conservative candidate Ali Akbar Nateq-Nouri by 152 votes to 38.
The other two candidates received a total of 13 votes, two ballots were cancelled and one was a blank vote, the agency added.
Iranians are voting for a successor to President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani in one of the sharpest political battles between conservatives and moderates since the 1979 Islamic revolution.
After a fiercely fought campaign and talk of fears of vote-rigging, the result looks likely to be a close contest between, Khatami and Nateq-Nouri -- both Shi'ite Moslem clerics.
Khatami, a moderate former culture minister popular with women, youths and intellectuals, was expected to sweep Tehran and some other major cities.
Nateq-Nouri, conservative speaker of parliament who enjoys the backing of important groups of Iran's conservative clergy and merchants, is stronger in rural areas.
Analysts gave the two other candidates, Mohammad Mohammadi Reyshahri and Reza Zavarei, no chance of winning.
State-run radio and television reported a high turnout and the Interior Ministry twice extended the time for voting by a total of four hours to 10 p.m. (1730 GMT).
Iranian analysts and Western diplomats said the vote was too close to call but they thought Nateq-Nouri had the edge because he was seen as an establishment figure.
The result is expected to be announced by Monday.
Thirty-three million Iranians aged 15 and over were eligible to vote at 33,180 mosques, schools and clinics turned into polling stations and guarded by 200,000 police.
